ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read City Shapes, we found squares in many different places.
Let’s review the words shape and square.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Use the shape and square Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, I will show you pictures of buildings and other things you might find in a city or town. Every picture will have at least one square in it. You will help me find all of the squares!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show the first Activity Card to the class. Ask, Where can you find a square? Invite children to point to all of the squares they see.
Extend Ask children to explain how they know that the object is a square. Encourage children to trace each square with their fingers, pointing out the corners and sides.
Repeat Continue the activity until all the cards have been shown.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Was it difficult to find some of the squares? Which ones were hardest? The squares were in lots of different places, and turned in lots of different ways. How could you tell they were still all squares?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model finding a square. Trace the object with your finger and describe it: There are four corners and four sides. All of the sides are the same length. Is this a square? Continue to trace objects as needed, asking each time, Is this a square?
Ask children to point to other shapes they see in the cards and name them. Encourage children to find squares in the classroom once they have found all of the squares in the cards.

In Spanish, the word for square is cuadrado. Cuatro is the word for four. Encourage Spanish speakers to remember that a square has four equal sides by thinking of the stems that both words have in common.

Give children a Pattern Block square to hold and turn as you show each card. Encourage them to reference the shape of the Pattern Block to help them find squares, and invite them to place the Pattern Block against the card over the squares they find.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-64913-0. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read City Shapes, we grouped rectangles by color.
Let’s review the words rectangle and group. Use the rectangle and group Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.
In this activity, I will show you pictures of shapes. You will tell me whether the shape is a rectangle or not. We will then group the shapes into two piles: rectangle and not rectangle.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Discuss squares as a type of rectangle. Rectangles have four corners and four straight sides. The opposite sides are the same length. Squares have four corners and four sides, and all the sides are the same length. Are squares a type of rectangle? Guide children to understand that squares are rectangles, but rectangles are not squares.

Ask Show the first Activity Card to the group. Ask children if the shape is a rectangle or not. Encourage children to explain why or why not the shape is a rectangle. Place the card into the correct pile: rectangle or not rectangle.
Repeat Continue the activity until all of the cards have been shown.

Extend Ask, How else can we group these cards? Challenge children to group the cards in several different ways (by shapes with corners and shapes without corners, by shapes with sides that are the same length and shapes with sides that are not all the same length, etc.)

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: How did you know which shape should go in each pile? What could we group in our classroom?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Describe each shape as you show the card. For example: This shape has three corners and three sides. Is it a rectangle? Remove the square cards from the deck if children have difficulty understanding that squares are also rectangles.

Encourage children to name the shapes that are not rectangles or squares, if they know them (circles, triangles). Invite them to explain how they know that the shape is a triangle or circle, and group them into three piles: rectangles, circles, and triangles.
In Spanish, the word for rectangle is rectángulo, and the word for group is agrupar. Share these cognates with children as you review vocabulary to help them remember the words.
Have children move to show you whether the answer is yes or no. They may stand for yes and sit for no, or move to a different side of the room for each answer.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-64913-0. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need the 2.2.2 Activity Cards from the previous lesson. Make sure you have at least one of each shape for this activity: circle, triangle, rectangle, and square.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read City Shapes, we saw many different shapes, including circles and triangles!
Let’s review the words circle and triangle.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Use the circle and triangle Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, I will show you a picture of a shape and tell you what the shape is. I might go too fast, though, and make a mistake! If I make a mistake, raise your hand to let me know.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Say the Shape Show the first Activity Card. Guess the shape correctly. For example, if the card is a rectangle, say, This is a rectangle. Check to make sure no children have raised their hands.

Make a Mistake Show the class the next card. This time, guess the shape incorrectly. For example, if the card is a circle, say, This is a triangle. Check to make sure children’s hands are up. Did I make a mistake? What shape is it? How can you tell?
Repeat Continue the activity, sometimes guessing the shape on the card correctly and sometimes making another mistake. When you make a mistake, always invite children to explain why.
Talk About Mistakes Ask children how they were able to catch your mistakes. Was it ever difficult to tell whether I made a mistake or not? What was hard about deciding what shape was on the card?

Show children at least one card of each shape (circle, rectangle, square, triangle) before making your first “mistake.” Describe and trace each shape with your finger as you show it: This shape has three sides. This is a triangle.

Ask whether a square card is a rectangle, and guide children to remember that squares are a type of rectangle. Consider adding classroom objects that are box- or ball-shaped to the activity, and have children practice identifying these shapes as well.

Review the words square and rectangle along with circle and triangle before starting the activity. Wait several seconds after you identify each shape to give multilingual learners sufficient time to process the word.
Add a kinesthetic component to the activity by asking children to make the shapes using their fingers as you discuss each shape. Using lamps for softer light can also reduce distracting stimuli.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-64913-0. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Our Neighborhood, we found shapes in many places in the town.
In this activity, you will find shapes in our classroom. I will tell you what shape I want you to find. Then, you will all stand near something that is that shape.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Find a Shape! Ask children to find the first shape: Find me a circle! Guide children to find something in the room that is shaped like a circle and stand next to it. Let children know it is okay if more than one child stands at the same shape and that they do not need to find only flat shapes—standing near a ball or other sphere is also correct.
What Is It? Ask each child to tell you what they have found. Guide them to use this frame: This is a . It is a circle.

Repeat Ask children to find more shapes in the room. Direct them to find at least one of each of the shapes they learned this week: circle, rectangle, triangle, square. You can extend the activity by saying, Find another circle!
Talk About Finding Shapes There are shapes everywhere! Which shape was the easiest to find? What shape was the hardest to find? Are any of these shapes in your home?
Using the 2.2.2 Activity Cards, show children each shape as you ask them to find it. You may also give each child a Pattern Block or a shape cut out of paper to use as a reference as they search.
Have children identify objects in the classroom that are a combination of different shapes. For example, Find something that has a circle and a rectangle! (a toy truck with wheels)
Review shape vocabulary before starting the activity. Use sentence clozes as necessary for classroom vocabulary: This is a cl . (clock) It is a c . (circle)
Repeat the shape you would like children to find as they search, so that they are reminded of what they are looking for: I can’t wait to see your circles!

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-64913-0. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
